skill.name: expo-cicd-workflows
skill.description: Helps understand and write EAS workflow YAML files for Expo projects. Use this skill when the user asks about CI/CD or workflows in an Expo or EAS context, mentions .eas/workflows/, or wants help with EAS build pipelines or deployment automation.
skill.summary: Helps understand and write EAS workflow YAML files for Expo projects. Use this skill when the user a...
skill.author: expo

security_audit.summary: Static analysis flagged 41 patterns including external commands and network access. All findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The scanner misclassified JavaScript template literals (backticks) as shell execution, the Fetch API as weak cryptography, and standard documentation URLs as security issues. This is a legitimate CI/CD helper skill with documented network access to Expo's official API endpoints.

low_findings.title: External Network Access
low_findings.description: Skill fetches schema from Expo API endpoints. Network access is documented and limited to official expo.dev and GitHub domains.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Network access is intentional and documented. URLs point to official Expo services for schema retrieval.

low_findings.title: External Command References in Documentation
low_findings.description: Documentation shows node command examples for running utility scripts. These are static documentation, not dynamic execution.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backtick characters flagged as shell execution are JavaScript template literals for string interpolation in documentation examples.

low_findings.title: Script Execution Patterns
low_findings.description: Utility scripts use child_process for npm install and script execution. Arguments are hardcoded strings, not user input.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Flagged backticks are template literals for string formatting, not shell command execution. No dynamic command construction found.

content.value_statement: Writing EAS CI/CD workflow YAML files requires understanding the schema and syntax. This skill helps generate, validate, and understand EAS workflows with up-to-date schema validation.
actual_capabilities: Generate EAS workflow YAML files from user requirements
Validate workflows against the official Expo schema
Fetch and use current schema definitions for job types and parameters
Explain workflow structure, expressions, and available contexts
Check job references and dependencies in workflows
limitations: Does not execute workflows or interact with EAS build services
Does not manage credentials or secrets for deployments
Cannot provision build resources or modify Expo configuration
Relies on network access to fetch current schema from Expo

use_cases.title: New Expo Project Setup
use_cases.description: Generate a complete EAS workflow file for a new Expo project with build, submit, and notify steps.
use_cases.target_user: Mobile developers new to EAS CI/CD

use_cases.title: Workflow Validation
use_cases.description: Validate existing workflow YAML files against the current schema and fix validation errors.

use_cases.title: Complex Pipeline Configuration
use_cases.description: Create multi-job workflows with dependencies, conditions, and custom expressions.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Workflow Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an EAS workflow file that builds my Expo app on every push to main. Use the 'eas-build' job type.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Stage Pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an EAS workflow with two jobs: first run tests, then build the app. The build job should only run if tests pass.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Expression Usage
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a workflow that uses GitHub context values for branch names and uses workflow_dispatch inputs for custom build parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Validation and Fixes
prompt_templates.prompt: Validate the workflow file at path/to/workflow.yml. If there are errors, explain what they mean and provide a corrected version.

output_examples.input: Create a basic EAS workflow that builds on push to main
output_examples.output:
```yaml
name: Build App
on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
jobs:
  build:
    name: Build
    runs-on: eas-build/latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
      - name: Install
        run: npm ci
      - name: Build
        run: npx expo export --platform all
```

best_practices: Always fetch the current schema before generating or validating workflows to ensure compatibility
Use the 'eas-build' job with specific version tags instead of 'latest' for reproducible builds
Validate generated workflows against the schema before deploying to production
anti_patterns: Using hardcoded values instead of expressions for dynamic configuration
Skipping validation after generating workflow files
Not checking job dependencies for circular references

faq.question: What job types does EAS support?
faq.answer: EAS supports 'eas-build' for building apps, 'eas-submit' for submission to app stores, and custom jobs. Fetch the schema to see all available job types and their parameters.

faq.question: How do I trigger workflows manually?
faq.answer: Add workflow_dispatch triggers to your on clause. Define inputs that users can provide when manually running the workflow from the Expo dashboard.

faq.question: Can I use secrets in workflows?
faq.answer: Yes, reference secrets using ${{ secrets.SECRET_NAME }}. Secrets are set in the Expo dashboard and never exposed in logs.

faq.question: What expression contexts are available?
faq.answer: Available contexts include github.* for GitHub information, inputs.* for workflow_dispatch values, needs.* for job outputs, and workflow.* for workflow metadata.

faq.question: How do I run jobs in parallel?
faq.answer: Define multiple jobs at the same level in the jobs section. By default they run in parallel. Add needs clauses to create dependencies and force sequential execution.

faq.question: Where do workflow files go?
faq.answer: Place workflow files in .eas/workflows/ directory with .yml or .yaml extension. The skill will create files in this location by default.
